Reviews.Title: “Try to avoid!”
Reviews.Author: fernandogrf
Reviews.Content: I paid over $50 to stay, but it's definetly NOT a 4 stars hotel. You can find much better in the same area for less. Windows had shots, bathroom all broken, pillows and bed with no sheets, no toilet paper. The only good thing about the hotel si the staff. It's not a touristic hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Look elsewhere...”
Reviews.Author: Keith W
Reviews.Content: I booked online so I wasn't familiar with the hotel when I arrived. The internet rate is like half the regular rate. But, even then... the room is dilapidated. The window was cracked. The toilet seat was broken. The carpet was threadbare. The few pieces of furniture in the lobby was falling apart. I went to the restaurant for a cup of ice, and the rude woman/maitre d' told me if I asked her again, she was going to charge me for the ice. The kitchen was open to the dining room, and looking at it, I didn't bother eating there even with the complimentary breakfast.

Reviews.Title: “Do not believe appearances”
Reviews.Author: frenchexpatriate
Reviews.Content: Booking online, i thought this hotel was decent. The pictures are a lie. For $35 you get ruin down room, with chipped furnitures of very bad taste and old carpet. The bath room is nice and pleasant. The place is hot (i do not remember if they have AC). The inside looks like an old hotel from the 60's. The buffet is good, but be careful, your free breakfast is not for the Buffet. Only for a tea, bread and juice. (i had to pay $7 extra for the buffet i had eaten without knowing that). The employees were nice and pleasant. MY REAL COMPLAIN IS : The room do not look as nice as they seem on the picture and it really look like a low class hotel in the lobby. If i were paying 15/20 USD i would understand but for $30+ you can get a lot better in DF. But the neighborhood is good. Only the area of the station is questionable.

Reviews.Title: “Basic hotel”
Reviews.Author: Guitarrero
Reviews.Content: Cheap, clean and basic hotel. Good location. Funeral agency right across the street...

Reviews.Title: “In need of a renovation but it'll do”
Reviews.Author: CupcakeTraveler
Reviews.Content: It is very in need of a renovation. It's very 1970s with its oranges, brown and red colours. Although it is outdated the rooms are kept very clean. We got a very large room with a living area. At first I thought it was grotty and old but It's cheap and the location makes up for it. You can walk to most places easily. The free breakfast is not the best but its free. Our room was at the back so it was hard for us to pick up the wireless. All in all I'd recomend this place for the location and it's cheapness, so long as you can put up with the terrible 70's decor.

Reviews.Title: “My Hotel of Choice when in the DF”
Reviews.Author: Satsuma932
Reviews.Content: I have stayed at this hotel many times and have never been disappointed. The staff is great, the service is good, and the location can't be beat. You are blocks from La Reforma and the CuauhtÃ©moc metro stop and within walking distance of almost anything you would want to do. The neighbourhood is quiet and safe and a little off the beaten path (touristically speaking). The rooms are clean and basic unless you opt for the minisuite which is worth the extra bucks if you spend significant time in the room. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone who wants a basic but well run and near everything place in the DF.

Reviews.Title: “Good for one or two nights”
Reviews.Author: artmos
Reviews.Content: We got there late, like around midnight. It was a little weird, but can't define how. Like a scary movie where nothing scary happens. It's true what others have said, small rooms, seem stuffy, lounge is very worn, seems, looks and feels old. People were friendly enough. It seems like the food is going to be good, but it's not. If you must stay here, stay, but there are many more options. You get what you pay for.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Prim, nice place to stay”
Reviews.Author: wgpittman
Reviews.Content: We checked in on Thursday, because had already spent a week with relatives, and it was time for the family to have some time to ourselves. We greated by very nice bell man and receptionist. We were taking care of in no time, and went straight to are room. I reserved a room for 4 ppl, and was very suprised when we got to are room to see three beds and two bathrooms, one on each end of the room. The room also had closets on each end. Not alot of outlets, so if you have electrical devices that need power, I would suggest bring a extention cord. The food in the resturant was good. Room service was very expediant, and order where right to the letter. I wont say I paid money to stay, I had points through my bank, so I used them to stay there, but it was still well worth it. You a couple blocks of the main road Reforma, which is where the Turri Bus (tourist bus) will pick you up for a guided tour of the city. Oh, let mention that its a double decker no roof tour bus. There is also a mall with in walking distance of the hotel also. The concierge was very nice to point things to do, and places to go. I would stay there again, if the oppurtunity ever came my way again.

Reviews.Title: “Bad bad experience”
Reviews.Author: tarynandcraig
Reviews.Content: skeevy concierge, dirty rooms, old carpet, awful breakfast (the wait staff wear swine flu masks - awful!), smelly and loud (the bar downstairs has live music and the walls are paper thin). Pay a little bit more and go somewhere else. Its not worth it. Looks like the hotel from the shining and the taxi driver the concierge ordered ripped me off (charged me 7 times what I would have paid elsewhere). never pay to use the internet, I haven't seen a slower computer since 1983.

Reviews.Title: “HUGE suite, good bed, fine neighborhood!”
Reviews.Author: jazzbaby88
Reviews.Content: Just stayed at the Hotel Prim - if it's space you want, this is the place for you! Rooms are plain but clean, junior suites are immense. IF you have no problem with maroon velveteen, you will have no problem with this place. Subway is a few blocks away, also the Artesanale market, Museo de Artes Populares.... And the hotel has a nightclub on the first floor, "The Cathedral of Bohemia", where old school Mexican crooners sing with LIVE musicians thurs-fri-sat.

Reviews.Title: “Great value at a very reasonable price.”
Reviews.Author: podroznik48
Reviews.Content: I had the pleasure of staying at the Prim on two occasions during my recent visit to Mexico. Although modest, accommodations are fully adequate. I had single room with a queen size bed comfortable bed with box spring. The room is equipped with night tables to either side of the headboard, dual light switches at the door and the beside the head board for the overhead light and the headboard lights, a desk with a large mirror and a chair. A large closet shares the wall with the large bathroom. The windows are large and open with drapes colour coordinated with the carpeting and the bed covering. There is a frosted vented window in the bathroom. All fixtures functioned well. I did not have to wait long for the hot water and the pressure was good in both rooms. Both rooms ( and baths) were very clean. Housekeeping staff do a very good job. I would recommend one of the interior rooms facing the courtyard over those facing the street. There is no view but they are quieter and larger. In the former, the TV is mounted on a wall bracket which I kept bumping with my head. In the latter, the TV is mounted on a table. The bellman and desk staff are excellent. They are all friendly, efficient and helpful. Most speak very good English but were patient when I tried to practice my very limited Espanol. Taxi rates to most relevant destinations are posted at the reception desk and hotel staff will arrange for taxi service on request. Drivers often try to charge above the posted rates, but relent when challenged. The hotel has a very good restaurant. The service is good, prices very reasonable and the food is tasty with a wide menu selection. I noticed that many people that worked in the area or lived nearby were regulars at breakfast and lunch. There is good security, as all entrants to the hotel must pass the bellman and the front desk. The hotel is well-located being two blocks from the Christopher Columbus monument on the Paseo de la Reforma. Centro Historico is readily accessible on foot. Even with my sore and wonky knees, I did not require transportation. The neighborhood appears to be safe and several mercados with a wide range of merchandise are nearby. The Turibus - a tour bus service with two routes that uses red double-decker buses - can be caught at the Columbus circle. The stop is not marked nor obvious but it was easy to ask for directions from passersby in front of the Fiesta Americana. For first time visitors, in my view, the Turibus is a must. It provides you with an excellent overview of the major sights and neighborhoods. With the day pass, you can get on and off as you wish. Enjoy.

Reviews.Title: “Charming, Friendly, and EXCELLENT value for money.”
Reviews.Author: kayt75
Reviews.Content: I arrived at the Mexico City Airport around 10:30pm (taxi cost 152MXN (about 12USD) and took less than 20mins, I think). Had a very simple check-in process (I had booked through Travelocity). Almost everyone I encountered during my stay spoke some English, and they managed not to laugh at my Spanish - both of which were greatly appreciated. Some of the decor in the rooms is a bit outdated and worn (think Motel 6), but for about $35/night (through Travelocity) I can't complain about a thing like that. What was most important to me was that it was VERY clean. The restaurant has good, tasty food at very reasonable prices. Lunches I had were between 4-6USD, dinners were in the 6-8USD range - even room service never cost me more than 9USD (depending on what you order, of course). The maid only leaves one bottle of water per room per day, but I simply left a note asking for two bottles and 20MXN/day as a tip (for both the water and the cleaning). There were always two bottles waiting for me when I got back to the room. Everyone on the staff was VERY friendly and helpful at all times. I would be glad to stay there again anytime. Only slight complaint .... The wifi in my room was slightly dubious - never above 25% and often dropping out. Which is fine for checking e-mail, but can be annoying when trying to skype people back home. There is also a public internet access computer in the lobby (which I didn't use). You can book tours through the hotel, and on someone else's advice that it was cheaper that way, I booked two of my tours through the hotel. The hotel uses an agency (based in another hotel) called Monopolis. I found the tour guide to be a nice person, but seemingly bored by her job. On our tour of Puebla she even left us alone for 30 minutes of "free time" while she sat in the Zocalo and smoked. And then, rather than being dropped off AT my hotel I was dropped off a block away (in the dark) with erroneous directions (if I hadn't already been out enough to recognize some of the buildings nearby I might have gotten seriously lost). The reason for this abrupt drop-off was that the road was supposedly closed. It was NOT closed, it was jam-packed with traffic moving at a snails pace and they just couldn't be bothered since we were already late getting back. As a single female traveler I didn't really appreciate being dropped off in the dark by myself, and so I canceled my subsequent tour with that company. Out of the tours I took, I would say Olympus was the best, but I can also say good things about GreyLine.

Reviews.Title: “Friendly place”
Reviews.Author: Nick-Prague
Reviews.Content: The rooms and the hotel in general would need an overall refreshing, but it is clean and the beds are good. The staff is extra friendly and helpful. Free safe, good advices, quiet. Advice: Try to have breakfast with a plate of fruits at the market by the tube entrance (10minutes walk). It's really worth it :)

Reviews.Title: “Great Location, But Very Basic Hotel”
Reviews.Author: FDNYCAPT
Reviews.Content: Stayed at Hotel Prim as part of a Travelocity air/hotel package to Mexico City for 4 nights in early in December 2008. Arrived at airport and took taxi to hotel. Cost about US $20. Hotel check-in was no problem. Hotel room was very, very basic, with two double beds with minimal toiletry amenities. Had to ask the maid for more bottled water, since room only had one small bottle. Rooms are not air-conditioned. Room door is paper thin and has very skimpy doorlock, had to keep a chair against doorknob at night. The room was very noisy due to evening hotel lounge entertainment ( I was on the 4th floor) and club next door. But who cares, I did not stay in room except to sleep, which was a bit tough due to nightclub noises and late night tourists arriving by bus at hotel. Location makes this place great. Only a few blocks from the main LA REFORMA boulevard, and also a stop for a (MUST DO) "TURISMO" red bus tour stop. If you have your own laptop, internet access code can be asked for at check-in desk, otherwise they had a PC setup sitting in the hotel lobby. I think they charge to use it, not sure. There is a very helpful and US speaking tour office guy right in the hotel lobby. He was from Boston, and was very helpful with any questions. I did not use the hotel restaurant for any meals, there is a small diner just down the end of the street. Make a right turn outside the lobby door, go across thestreet past the glitzy funeral parlor (with classic hearses parked in front) and go to end of street. Good food, cheap. There is also a "WINGS" (a Mexico version of a DENNY's) located a few blocks further on LA REFORMA. Ask anyone at the hotel how to get there. Good food, also fairly cheap. Only problems encountered at this hotel was on the first night. My wife and I went into the hotel lounge where there was live entertainment going in.. The sign on on the door said there was a 40 peso surcharge, so I asked the guy at the the front desk if this applied to hotel guests, and he said "No." After we sat down and ordered some drinks the lounge manager came over and told us that there was an 80 peso service charge, so I argued that the sign said "40" and he said that "was before 8PM." Not that big a deal, the cost of three beers, 2 good size wines for the wife and the 80 peso "lounge charge" came out to less than US$17. Can't even drink that cheap in New York City. But watch out for this "bait and switch" at this hotel. The maid service on our floor was not up to par. We had to ask them for extra bottles of water several days. Oh yes, if you need a hairdryer (which are not is the rooms), they ask you to leave a 100 peso deposit at the front desk. The location of the hotel is great. You are within very short walking distance to the famous Mercado Artesanal La Ciudadela (1 block south of Parque JosÃ© MarÃ­a Morelos, Col. JuÃ¡rez,). Open every day about 10-5, the bustling Mercado Artesanal La Ciudadela bursts with the widest range of wares and the best bargains in the capital. The public park just across the street hosts public dancing on the weekends, and also go there during the Sunday afternoon to see Mayan cultural dancers. Free, and worth the trip here to shop till you drop. There is also a great sandwich (Tortas) shop about 5-6 blocks ( 10 minutes walk) from the Mercado, and DEFINITELY worth the trip to eat cheap. Located in a neighboorhood featuring plumbing/lighting stores, find the â€œCafeteria El Cuadrilateroâ€� a very small place located on Luis Moya # 73, Col. Centro Historico. MASSIVE Tortas (sandwiches), very small price! The place is owned by a Lucha Libre Wrestler, Super Astro, and is easy to spot mid-street by the many masked wrestlers painted on the sign. Go here, and don't be afraid to walk from the Mercado , the neigborhood is safe. For a review with a slideshow, see web site: http://jesuschairez.blogspot.com/2008/11/lucha-libre-tortas-yes.html (Use Google Maps to see exact location). The closet METRO station near the hotel (name "BALDERAS") is also located at the far corner of this Park, about 4 blocks (10 minutes walk) from the hotel, and is THE BEST WAY to get around ANYWHERE in Mexico City , CHEAP ($0.35) and SAFE. However, being from New York City, I know what to keep my eyes open for. First rule: don't act like a tourist. Act as if you know exactly where you are going. Rule #2: Don't travel during rush hours or after dark, and keep your wallet in front pocket , your eyes open and your antennas up. You can go anywhere in the city very easily, and SAVEa ton of cash in the process. IN fact, my wife and I were traveling with carry-on luggage, so we decided to use the METRO back to the airport, which was fast and efficient. Just make sure you go to the "TERMINAL AEREA" station on the Number 5 line, and NOT the "AEROPUERTO" station on the Number 1 line. The $20 saved on taxi fare went a long way to buy some cheap eats at the many food concessions at the airport before we departed. Get a great METRO MAP to print out at this link: http://nanotube.msu.edu/nt04/img-var/MEX-metromap.jpg All in all, the HOTEL PRIM is a basic "Motel 6" type hotel that offers few amenities, but location and price can't be beat. If you are looking for a money saving stay with basic requirements, you can't go wrong.

Reviews.Title: “great doorman”
Reviews.Author: nicedog
Reviews.Content: good hotel with interesting surroundings the doorman was a real gem

Reviews.Title: “Loved the service”
Reviews.Author: ehecatl23
Reviews.Content: The people and service were excellent. My room was in good condition and all of the staff were polite, considerate, and helpful. I never needed to ask the maid for anything. She always made sure that I was fully stocked with all items needed.

Reviews.Title: “Good rates but issues”
Reviews.Author: Horatio_Jitterbug
Reviews.Content: We were looking for cheap hotels and got a recommendation from a friend to stay here because it's relatively centrally located in Mexico City for first time visitors wanting to check out historic sites and hip neighborhoods. Rooms are pretty modest but we weren't planning on watching TV all day so that wasn't an issue. $50 for a bed, shower and TV isn't bad. They have lockboxes at lobby desk for passports, etc. There was some construction going on in neighborhood and street nearby was pretty noisy at night- loud enough that I was happy I brought along earplugs. If you're a light sleeper looking for pampering/luxury- this isn't the place for you. I live in NYC so wasn't freaked out by neighborhood, but one of those transitional areas where at night felt a bit desolate at times walking around. You're a 10 minute cab ride from all this historic stuff downtown and cool neighborhoods like Condessa and Roma. There are alot bigger chain hotels with subpar restaurants in area, but if you walk around neighborhood there are quite a few good hole in the wall mom and pop places to eat breakfast/lunch for $5/person- some good homecookin'. Ideal hotel if you don't mind noise, aren't freaked out by dark/transitional neighborhoods at night, and looking for a reasonable place to stay that's 10 min cab ride to touristy spots.

Reviews.Title: “Prim is perfect for the price”
Reviews.Author: MairzieDoats
Reviews.Content: Three of us stayed overnight at the Prim Hotel prior to our flight home to Toronto. We reserved online and were welcomed cordially on arrival and shown to a room with 2 double beds and 2 bathrooms! which was very convenient. The room was clean, comfortable and quiet. The staff were friendly and helpful when we needed help. The area was middle-class residential and we were able to walk to the Zocalo and back. To be picky - the TV was scratchy, the view from the windows was other windows across the roof, and we were disappointed at the instant coffee for breakfast. But for the price, it was entirely satisfactory. Recommended for budget-minded people more interested in sightseeing than luxury accommodations. Signed: Sandra, Chris and Nola in Toronto, Canada

Reviews.Title: “It was good - We would stay again to save $$$”
Reviews.Author: msbianca2
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for about 3-4 nights in March 06. We paid VERY little for this hotel which was good. LOCATION: The hotel is in a decent location. Itâ€™s about a 5 minute walk to the main street (zona de something). We were also a 5 minute walk from the hop on hop off bus for Mexico City. Itâ€™s very close to a number of corner stores and little restaurants which was good. Major tour companies do pick up at this hotel. ROOMS: Think of a college dorm room. It was very small with an old bed, a TV which does not need a remote since all you have to do is reach over to change the channels (the room was that small), a built in desk, closet, and a fairly spacious bathroom with nice old tile work. The room had no A.C. Thank God it was nice and cool when we were there. Our window was facing the inside of the courtyard so we got a little breeze. Doors are thin and only have one lock which may not be secure for some. We just put the chair in front of it at night. Maid service was good as we tipped daily. The room was clean but the bed spread looked a little worn with two small measly pillows. The shower pressure and temperature was great! This hotel services many people - from large sports team, "nightly visitors", partiers, tourists, and everything in between. SERVICE: The font desk was nice. I did run into problems at the restaurant for breakfast. I think they were trying to cheat me on paying more. I found someone at the front desk who helped resolved the situation graciously. The front desk called taxis for us when needed and was very helpful. I did not quite expect that level of service for this type of hotel OVERALL: If youâ€™re going to be out and about ALL day long, I see NOTHING wrong with this hotel. I don't think I would be able to bear it in the middle of summer though with no A.C. This hotel is great for people who donâ€™t want to spend much on accommodations in Mexico City. We chose this hotel because we wanted to save money for another high end hotel in another city in Mexico. I think it was worth it. I would stay here again with no doubts.

Reviews.Title: “Not a hotel I would recommend”
Reviews.Author: phlinq
Reviews.Content: Earlier I had posted on the forum if anyone recommended a hotel with a/c. Believe me you NEED it during this month. I gave into the comments that it gets chilly at night, so I thought I wouldn't need a/c during my stay. Well this is true if you stay in a room that gets a breeze through the window. Otherwise, you will be miserable with no cool air flowing. The hotel did not offer any fans either. I asked repeatedly. I didn't like the way the hotel was laid out. Think of a square. The rooms are lined along in a square shape and hollow in the middle, with the window facing the hollow area. Yes, there is only one window in the room and one in the restroom. Guests from across my hotel room and the floor rooms above could see through my window, which was also directly in front of my bed, so I had to keep my curtain closed. This didn't help with the whole cooling situation. My first impression of the room was...oh no. Many of the guest were young rude kids that stayed up every and all night yelling from outside their windows to other guests at either the same floor level or lower level rooms. During my first night, a Chinese foreigner was up yelling at them for about 30 minutes. I finally was fed up and called the front desk to ask them to stop shouting. They continued on for about another hour whistling, and making vulgar noises. My family came into town to spend some time with me, but I didn't want my them to stay at this hotel and experience what I had on the first night. I put them up at a different hotel that cost $35/night. I was paying $45/night. The second night, everything happened just as the first. I got up around 1a.m. and walked to my parent's hotel to get some sleep. The third and final night I was there, the some of the male guests kept eyeing and following me around. They made me feel unsafe. I waited four hours, before I went into my room because I didn't want them to see what room I was staying in. I couldn't sleep, worring if they had figured out what room I was in. They did knock on my door a few times and called my phone, but I didn't answer either. The hotel offers internet service, but it cost $10 to use. I recommend you take an iron for your clothes, alarm clock, plug adapter for your appliances, and extra toiletries, and fan. These aren't offered by the hotel. The front lobby of the hotel is misleading to what the actual rooms look like. It would have been nice to have marble floors. If you do choose to stay here, the cab ride is only $4.00 from the airport. The taxis at the airport will try to get $40 out of you if you don't purchase a ticket at the booth. The hotel itself offers this service, but it costs $14 each way. It is more economical to take the red and white taxis. That is what I rode in for all my rounds. To the Zona Rosa, I walked. It would have cost less than $1.50 in a taxi. For eating out on Saturdays and Sunday nights, I recommend "Wings". They have half price menus after 8:00 p.m. The arrachera steak is excellent and costs $6.98 dollars for a 10oz. I don't know why anyone would pay more than $10 per person to eat in Mexico City, even if it is a buffet. More than that you are getting ripped off. This was the only restaurant I ate at. The other times I ate from stands along the street. Birria (goat meat) stands at La Basilica are excellent and so are the Gorditas. I bought the meat by the kilo to make my own tacos with flour tortillas that are sold at a store down the block. This tortilla store also makes these great jalepeno tortillas and also ones made out of wheat. At La Basilica, I was able to see the Virgen Mary of Guadalupe, but I went at a bad time. I went during the pilgrimage of the entire state of Querretaro. There were thousands and thousands of people there. I went on a Sunday because I read online that the Basilica is closed on Mondays. This is not true. I also went to the Teotihuacan pyramids. There is a museum that closes at 5:30pm on Sundays. Take sunblock, shades, and a hat. You will need them. Xochimilco was awesome. Take a picnic basket and ice chest on the boat and have a party. Be careful of some of the shopping districts in Mexico City; they are not all safe.
